discussion.author: Casteran
palmskog
discussion.comment: @Casteran indeed, `rewrite ... in ...` is not an idiom recommended in the SSReflect world (it indicates inadequate context management via `move`). However, rather than fixing this in the PR, maybe we can merge the PR? And you can fix it at some later point, or you can ask me to drop support for 8.13 in CI.

discussion.author: Casteran
discussion.comment:
> @Casteran indeed, `rewrite ... in ...` is not an idiom recommended in the SSReflect world (it indicates inadequate context management via `move`). However, rather than fixing this in the PR, maybe we can merge the PR? And you can fix it at some later point, or you can ask me to drop support for 8.13 in CI.

Well, I think it'd be better to respect SSReflect's idioms as much as possible.
So, you propose to merge into master, then I replace in priority the `rewrite ... in` which deal with setoids, then the others. For a few days, I will have 8.13 failures.
Right?

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: @Casteran usually it's a good idea to have a green CI. I'm thinking we could just disable the Docker CI for 8.13 if you don't mind, then re-enable it once you fix the `rewriting .. in` (ping me in the pull request).

discussion.author: Casteran
discussion.comment:
@palmskog I just removed fifty occurrences of `rewrite ... in ...` in the Gaia-Bridge files. The result isn't pretty, but next weeks I will work on these files:
   - improve the use of `move` and derivates 
   - make some decidable predicates boolean functions (e.g. `path`)
When it looks better, we may make and advertise a `1.0` release ...

discussion.comment: This seems to work well. However, the update to Coq 8.14 creates new warnings that are reported in the Alectryon snippets (missing locality for `Instance`).

discussion.author: Zimmi48
discussion.comment: This warning is already disabled in `_CoqProject`. Maybe we need a way to also report the warning disabling when calling SerAPI through Alectryon.

discussion.author: cpitclaudel
discussion.comment: For warnings that can be unconditionally disabled, we could use `Global Set Warnings "-…".` in a core file.  I'm don't think that SerAPI has a way to customize warnings from the command line otherwise, but maybe there's a [protocol command that we could use for that if the `Set Warnings` route is not desirable.

discussion.author: Zimmi48
discussion.comment: `Global Set Warnings` is frowned upon because of the transitive reach (beyond project boundaries). That's why command line arguments are usually preferred for that kind of stuff. That being said, in this precise case, I can also fix the warning by adding `#[ global ]` annotations everywhere they are missing.

discussion.author: cpitclaudel
discussion.comment: Makes sense, thanks!

review_discussion.author: palmskog
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
\newcommand{\Coqcommunity}{Coq-community\xspace}
```
I think we want to put the `\emph{...}` where we actually use the macro, for more flexibility. Do we really want Coq-community emphasized everywhere? I think this is what is causing the issues with `~\cite{XY}`.

review_discussion.author: palmskog
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
The \Hydras project, part of \Coqcommunity~\cite{CoqCommunity} aims to be an experimental platform for the collaborative development of commented libraries of formal proofs. \Coqcommunity is a community organization that we have founded in 2018 with two goals in mind: providing a solution for the long-term maintenance of interesting Coq packages, and working collaboratively on documentation projects. The \Hydras project demonstrates that these two goals are not independent: interesting Coq packages can become the basis for new documentation.
```
If you apply the fix to `\Coqcommunity` macro, we should be able to use the standard `~\cite{XY}`.

review_discussion.author: Casteran
review_discussion.comment: I agree with with your suggested change.  If we want to emphasize for instance the first occurrence of Coq-community, in the paper, it is still possible to write `\emph{\Coqcommunity}` . Is it usual ?

review_discussion.author: palmskog
review_discussion.comment: Yes, I think writing `\emph{\Coqcommunity}` is the standard way to do it.

discussion.author: Casteran
discussion.comment:
> Here is an initial draft adding the Compare operational typeclass discussed in #74.

Thanks !
> 
> There are some low-level improvements to make, but also some questions to think about:
> 
>     * Should there be any infix notation at all for the Compare typeclass? I add here `x <?> y`, but I don't use it in the code, since it's such as big change.

May be we can just give the infix for a kind of compatibility with the notations in Standard Library. Personally, I will use
the  synstx "compare x y" in the code.

> 
>     * I get rid of some more boolean functions for convenience. I think it looks reasonable, but there are some tradeoffs in that the Decision typeclass shows up in a lot of places.
> 
> 
> @Casteran could you give a high-level assessment whether this PR is worth polishing up and merging? Or maybe it should stay an experiment?

I have had a look at your code, and found very reasonable to get rid of the boolean function whenever possible. 
We do not have sequences like `unfold lt, lt_b`any more :-)

The cost will be perhaps to add a documentation on Decision in the book (but it will be interesting anyway !).

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
I improved the organization of lemmas and did some fixes based on the discussion above. In particular, I removed the infix notation for `compare` for now and updated some material on the `Comparable` typeclass for the new (in my opinion improved) definition. I think this should now be ready to merge.

Since the `Decision` typeclass was not the subject of this PR, I would prefer to another PR with material in the book about `Decision`.

discussion.author: Zimmi48
discussion.comment:
> Less than 16 minutes for the total duration of the Nix CI including the documentation job (which takes 9 minutes). That's 10 minutes less than the doc pipeline.

Actually, we are even faster at the second run because all the dependencies (in particular SerAPI and its own dependencies) are already built and in cache already. Now, the total duration of the pipeline is 14m40s.

There is still an issue though, which makes the pipeline slower than it should, which is that `make html` isn't compatible with `cachedMake` (probably because of timestamps being wrong) and therefore vo files are rebuilt in the `build-doc` job. We can fix this issue by moving the coqdoc build to the previous step (building `hydra-battles-single`).

@Casteran feel free to roll back my SSReflect proof changes if you want. Also, recall that you can get `lia` and `nia` to work with MathComp operators if you install the package `coq-mathcomp-zify`, and do after the usual MathComp requires:

```coq
From mathcomp Require Import zify.
```

discussion.author: Casteran
discussion.comment:
@palmskog 

Regarding José Grimms' work:
What about the following text (in the Related work section) ?

" The GaÏa project ~\url{https://github.com/coq-community/gaia} maintains this library on the Coq-community platform. Integration of both libraries would be an extremely interesting project. "


I am very enthusiastic about the idea of making both libraries compatible, even though it may be a huge work.
Depending on the modelization of ordinals one is considering, the proofs of a same statement, e.g. the associativity of addition, may be completely different, and it's interesting to make all these proofs available (at least on the documentation). José Grimm's modelization could also play the same role as Schütte's : a mathematical reference for our data structures.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
@Casteran that sounds good to me, but one might also hint at what the project would entail, for example:
```latex
The Gaia project (\url{https://github.com/coq-community/gaia}) maintains
Grimm's theory of ordinals as part of coq-community on GitHub. Integration
of the present ordinal theory with Gaia, i.e., relating the different notions of ordinals
and transferring relevant results, would be an interesting project.
 ```

> What about the following text (in the Related work section) ?
> 
> " The GaÏa project ~\url{[https://github.com/coq-community/gaia}](https://github.com/coq-community/gaia%7D) maintains this library on the Coq-community platform. Integration of both libraries would be an extremely interesting project. "
> 
> I am very enthusiastic about the idea of making both libraries compatible, even though it may be a huge work.
> Depending on the modelization of ordinals one is considering, the proofs of a same statement, e.g. the associativity of addition, may be completely different, and it's interesting to make all these proofs available (at least on the documentation). José Grimm's modelization could also play the same role as Schütte's : a mathematical reference for our data structures.

@palmskog @Zimmi48 @thery 

  I'm just starting to create a new experimental branch "Bridge" for proving relationships between Hydra-battle's and Gaia's ordinals. I hope to commit a partial draft soon.
  By the way, opam's coq-gaia seems to be still for coq-8.12. So, I'm using the version downloaded from coq-community.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: If @thery doesn't mind, I will do a release of Gaia for MathComp 1.12.0 and Coq 8.13.0 and beyond.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: @Casteran @Zimmi48 also, since Gaia is a big dependency (> 5 min to check, from what I remember), I think we should organize any bridge as a separate package (`coq-gaia-hydras`?) and directory under `theories`. I think it wouldn't be nice for people who just want play around with hydras to have to wait for Gaia to install first. But let's continue that discussion when there is stuff to merge to `master` here.

discussion.author: Casteran
discussion.comment:
There seems to be a lot of warnings  of the form «  Unused variable x catches more than one case » , for instance in definitions like

Fixpoint mult (alpha beta : T1) :T1 :=
  match alpha,beta with
 |  zero, y  => zero
 |  x, zero => zero
 |  ocons zero n _, ocons zero n' _ => 
                 ocons zero (Peano.pred((S n) * (S n'))) zero
 |  ocons a n b, ocons zero n' b' =>  
                 ocons a (Peano.pred((S n) * (S n'))) b
 |  ocons a n b, ocons a' n' b' =>
     ocons (a + a') n' ((ocons a n b) * b')
 end
where  "alpha * beta" := (mult alpha beta) : t1_scope.

Is giving a name to an unused variable (in the right hand side of a match clause) bad style ?
If so, I can replace a lot os such occurrences by the anonymous variable _.
But, as readability is concerned, the second clause of the match looks like the equation x * zero = zero.

Perhaps @Zimmi48 knows why this warning was introduced.

@palmskog or @Zimmi48, Pierre is uncomfortable with merging so can you please check and act accordingly?
What I did was:
git rm fib.v make_fib_tests.txt stub.ml
copies the files back in place
git add fib.v make_fib_tests.txt stub.ml
git commit

This way the author appears normally in the git history.
I have more improvements to propose on the fib.v file, in future version, I will remove the comments "author: Yves Bertot" that do not belong in the file itself.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: One issue to keep in mind is that each PDF is around 1MB. Git does have delta-compression, but with hundreds of commits, repo size could become a factor.

discussion.author: anton-trunov
discussion.comment: @palmskog Does this workflow actually commit build artifacts? I would expect it to upload them to an external storage.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
> Does this workflow actually commit build artifacts? I would expect it to upload them to an external storage.

I based my comment on the following:
> the PDF will be deployed to GitHub Pages

discussion.author: anton-trunov
discussion.comment: I see, thanks. I'm wondering if we could just link latest artifact from Github Pages.

discussion.author: Zimmi48
discussion.comment:
> One issue to keep in mind is that each PDF is around 1MB. Git does have delta-compression, but with hundreds of commits, repo size could become a factor.

This is avoided by the fact that the gh-pages branch is erased / force-pushed at every deploy. It never contains more than one commit.

For the record, my initial plan was indeed to push an artifact and not a GitHub Pages branch, but GitHub Actions won't allow viewing the PDF in the browser in that case (it encapsulates it in a zip archive). GitLab CI is superior here, but using it would introduce additional complexity (not worth it IMHO).

made available as an artifact to ease reviewing.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: @Zimmi48 @Casteran this is unfortunately still quite far from best practices w.r.t. makefiles and build scripting. If you want, I can make a PR with some changes (after this is merged). In particular, I would advise against generating a file list via a shell script. Even though it is somewhat tedious to list all `.v` files in `_CoqProject`, this is currently the most stable option until we get final Dune support.
